title: Тетрис
text: 20th century's definitive puzzle game from the Soviet Union

title: The Creator
subtitle: Alexey Leonidovich Pajitnov
text:
Born in Moscow in 1955, Pajitnov.

 A long-time fan of puzzles and mathematics, his creation was conceived in the Soviet Academy of Sciences. First: a black and green version for the Elektronika 60. Then, Pajitnov requested an adaptation to the IBM PC. After being copied and distributed among the few people with computers in the URSS, it was licensed by Mirrorsoft.

title: Journey to the West
subtitle: How this game reached us.
text: More and more Western and Japanese developers started investing in adapting and distributing more versions of Tetris. Even during the era of Gorbachev's perestroika, commercializing Soviet products internationally was an endeavor as bureaucratic as any other imaginable ask in the USSR. Elorg, the former Soviet Union's central organism for import and exports of computer software, seized control of the property. From now on, it interveined in all business deals and retained a large part of all versions' revenue.

title: Japan rises
subtitle: How it reached your pocket, in more than one way
text:
After a hugely competetive set of negociations 1989 would represent the year Tetris reached millions of households around the world.

During this year Nintendo published versions for its NES and Gameboy consoles, which became a huge commercial success: both versions combined sold more than 43 million units worldwide.
